results.title: Moving to Maldon
results.brief_description: Eric and Debra Watson came to Maldon for a long weekend, walked around and fell in love with the town. They saw a church for sale and three days later purchased it and moved from Melbourne. The town felt like home from their first visit and while they feel close enough to the city, their kids have the chance of growing up in a safe country environment where they can walk everywhere and just be kids.

results.title: Castlemaine Community Lunch
results.brief_description: The Castlemaine Community Lunch is a weekly event organised by the Castlemaine Community House. It brings people together in a warm and welcoming environment, encouraging and nurturing friendships and connections. Attended by locals, old and new, it is also a chance to welcome newcomers into the community.

results.title: The Gervasoni Family Estate: life in the Yandoit houses
results.brief_description: Maurie Gervasoni’s grandfather settled in Newstead during the Victorian gold rush in the 1860’s and quickly designed and built a family estate. A love of music and dancing made the Yandoit houses a destination for vibrant country living. The stone house and former stables presently sit as a relic, but Maurie hopes that one day the place will be restored to its former glory.

results.title: ACMI in the regions: Stories from Mount Alexander
results.brief_description: The Shire of Mount Alexander is located in the central region of Victoria. These nine stories cover the towns Castlemaine, Newstead and Maldon. Locals from the region discuss living in the country, the reasons for choosing to living in these towns and the community spirit so crucial to the region’s survival.

results.title: Newstead Community Garden
results.brief_description: When the town of Newstead held a summit in 2008, the idea of a community garden grew out of it. With the help of a grant and the support of locals and volunteers, the land surrounding the All Saints Anglican Church has become a thriving biodynamic garden. It is a great place for the community to come together, dig and get to know one another.

results.title: King of Maldon
results.brief_description: Glenn Roy, also known as ‘Kinga’, has lived in Maldon for 40 years and is considered a local treasure. Once named the King of Maldon, he takes care of all the elderly in the town doing all sorts of odd jobs for them. He has an obsession for collecting Victor lawnmowers which keeps him busy, as does his dogs and the various bands he performs in. His motto is to be happy and to make sure the town is happy, even if that means putting on a tutu and fishnets for the town’s Mardi Gras Easter parade.

results.title: Young Philly
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Phillip is a 20-year-old Hip Hop artist from Mildura who won the prestigious Noel Tovey Achievement Award in 2010 (for Emerging Artist). Despite having a difficult start in life, Phil is intent on living a positive life and breaking the negative stereotypes associated with young Aboriginal people. He shares his passion for rapping with a desire to become a youth worker in the hopes of one day establishing a youth centre for Indigenous kids in Mildura.

results.title: Sustainable Ouyen
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Several years ago a group of Ouyen Primary School students petitioned their local council to adopt a community-recycling program. To everybody’s surprise the council not only provided an unprecedented household recycling service but did so at a loss. Since that time the community has launched a number of forward thinking initiatives with solar power, sustainable agriculture and improved water usage. Whether it’s the Ouyen Football Club, High School or local farmers, there’s an understanding that sustainable practices must be employed now in order for future Ouyen generations to benefit.

Whether it’s the Ouyen Football Club, High School or local farmers, there’s an understanding that sustainable practices must be employed now in order for future Ouyen generations to benefit.

results.title: Sunraysia Ukulele Network
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: An unlikely group of people come together once a month to share their love of the Ukulele. They meet on the last Sunday of each month at a local landmark called The Old Cottage where they play the uke and have a sing-a-long. Everyone is welcome, from beginners to more experienced players, the door is always open.
